DOCNAME: CASE OF JATAIRWAYS, A.D. BEOGRAD v. SLOVENIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Reasonable time);Violation of Article 13 - Right to an effective remedy (Article 13 - Effective remedy)
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE proceedings before ORG were instituted against the applicant company by CARDINAL of its former employees , following their dismissal from work .
CARDINAL . By DATE when the Convention came into force in respect of GPE , the court held one hearing .

CARDINAL . A hearing was scheduled for DATE but ORG was unable to serve the summons to the applicant company as the latter changed its address without informing the court . The court therefore ordered that all further court ’s writings would be served on the applicant company by a publication on the court ’s notice board .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing in the absence of the applicant company and issued its decision , deciding that the dismissal of the plaintiffs by the applicant company was illegal and ordering the applicant company to acknowledge their rights from the employment contract and to pay them outstanding salaries . The decision was served on the applicant company on DATE through diplomatic channels . The applicant company appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher Labour and ORG upheld the first instance court ’s decision in the part concerning the illegality of the dismissal , annulled the remainder of the decision and remitted the case back to the first instance court .

CARDINAL . In the remitted proceedings the court ’s writings were initially served on the applicant company . Later on , the applicant company authorized a NORP lawyer , PERSON , to represent it in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first instance court held a hearing and decided to examine the claims of CARDINAL of the plaintiffs separately from the remaining claims . On DATE it issued its decision on the claims of the remaining plaintiffs and upheld their claim concerning the payment of the outstanding salaries . The applicant company appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher ORG requested the applicant company ’s representative to present his power of attorney .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the plaintiffs filed a motion for interim order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court made the interim order requested .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an objection against the interim order .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court dismissed the applicant ’s objection . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher Labour and ORG quashed the decision of DATE and remitted the case back to the first instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again dismissed the applicant ’s objection against the interim order . The applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher Labour and ORG upheld the applicant ’s appeal , annulled the first - instance court ’s decision of DATE and dismissed the plaintiffs’ motion for an interim order .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Higher Labour and ORG partially upheld the applicant company ’s appeal against the decision of CARDINAL DATE and modified the decision of the first instance court in the part concerning the payment of interest and dismissed the remainder of the appeal . The applicant company and the plaintiffs lodged an appeal on points of law .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company was reminded by the court to pay the court fee for lodging an appeal on points of law .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company was reminded by the court to pay the court fee for its reply to the appeal on points of law lodged by the plaintiffs .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed both appeals on points of law and upheld the decision of ORG . The applicant company lodged a constitutional appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company was again reminded to pay the outstanding court fees .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant company ’s constitutional appeal . The decision was served on its representative on DATE .
